questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for preconceptional advice. She has been married for 2 years and would like to conceive within the next year. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and follows a balanced diet. She takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. She has adequate knowledge of the fertile days of her menstrual cycle. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supplementation of folic acid (0.4–0.8 mg/day) is recommended in all patients trying to conceive. Ideally, women should begin taking a supplement ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continue with this dose until 12 weeks of gestational age to meet the increased demand of folate due to fetal neural tube development and maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. If there is a folate deficiency, neural tube defects (e.g., anencephaly, meningomyelocele) and megaloblastic anemia may occur.

B) INCORRECT:

In the absence of severe deficiency, excessive intake of vitamin A is contraindicated in pregnant women and women who may become pregnant within the next 60 days. Vitamin A doses greater than the recommended dietary allowance in pregnancy (> 770 mcg/day or > 2560 units/day) may cause craniofacial malformations or central nervous system, heart, or thymus abnormalities in the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 supplementation is recommended for pregnant women who adhere to a vegan diet since vitamin B12 is mainly found in red meat, fish, and dairy products. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to maternal and fetal megaloblastic anemia. This patient does not follow a vegan diet and is not yet pregnant, making vitamin B12 supplementation unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation of 30–60 mg/d is recommended during pregnancy to meet the increased iron demand due to maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. Iron deficiency in pregnancy may cause maternal and fetal anemia and increases the risk of placental insufficiency. Since this patient shows no symptoms of iron deficiency anemia, such as fatigue or pallor, iron supplementation is not necessary prior to conception.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who are underweight can experience difficulty conceiving. If the patient were underweight and having problems becoming pregnant, gaining weight might be advised. Gaining extra weight prior to conception is not necessary in this case, as the woman has a normal BMI. Over the course of pregnancy, she should gain 25–35 lbs (about 11–16 kg).
questions.hint: Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of neural tube defects such as spina bifida and anencephaly in the fetus?

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravid woman at 15 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She has not been taking prenatal vitamins and admits to consuming alcohol regularly. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 15-week gestation. A quadruple screening test shows markedly elevated maternal serum α-fetoprotein. Maternal serum concentrations of β-human chorionic gonadotropin, estriol, and inhibin A are normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fetal alcohol syndrome is one of the most common causes of intellectual disability in the US and may manifest with various congenital abnormalities (e.g., microcephaly, heart defects, limb dislocation). It is not associated with changes in AFP levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal trisomy 21 is characterized by intellectual disability, flat facies, congenital heart disease, and prominent epicanthal folds. It is the most common chromosomal disorder. Prenatal screening results typically show decreased levels of AFP and unconjugated estriol, and increased levels of inhibin A and β-hCG.

C) INCORRECT:

A molar pregnancy is a benign uterine tumor that typically results in low levels of maternal serum AFP, low levels of unconjugated estriol, increased levels of inhibin A, and extremely high levels of β-hCG.

D) INCORRECT:

Holoprosencephaly is the failure of the right and left hemispheres of the brain to separate. It may be seen with trisomy 13 and fetal alcohol syndrome. Maternal serum AFP levels are not typically increased in cases of holoprosencephaly.

E) CORRECT:

Increased levels of maternal serum AFP with normal levels of β-hCG, inhibin A, and unconjugated estriol are characteristic of neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida cystica), in which there is a connection between the spinal canal and the amniotic cavity due to failed closure of the anterior or posterior neuropores. Neural tube defects are also associated with increased levels of acetylcholinesterase in the amniotic fluid, which results from leakage of fetal cerebrospinal fluid. The diagnosis can be confirmed prenatally in most cases via ultrasound.

Spina bifida occulta is characterized by normal AFP levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Fetal trisomy 18 is a rare and fatal congenital disease that is characterized by intellectual disability, clenched fists, prominent occiput, low-set ears, and congenital heart disease. Prenatal screening results typically show decreased levels of AFP, unconjugated estriol, and β-hCG.
questions.hint: Periconceptional folate supplementation (present in prenatal vitamins) significantly decreases the risk of this developmental defect, which can be detected in utero on ultrasound and via elevated maternal serum α-fetoprotein (AFP) levels.

questions.text: A male newborn is delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. The mother has no medical insurance and did not receive prenatal care. Physical examination shows microcephaly and ocular hypotelorism. There is a single nostril, cleft lip, and a solitary central maxillary incisor. An MRI of the head shows a single large ventricle and fused thalami. This patient's condition is most likely caused by abnormal expression of which of the following protein families?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The sonic hedgehog (SHH) protein of the hedgehog protein family plays a critical role during embryonic development and morphogenesis of the central nervous system, craniofacial structures, and limbs. Single gene mutations in the SHH signaling pathway result in malformations such as holoprosencephaly and midfacial defects, as seen here. Holoprosencephaly is also associated with other inherited or acquired conditions such as trisomy 13 and fetal alcohol syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

The transforming growth factor (TGF) protein family plays an essential role in the embryonic development of bone, cartilage, and skeletal muscle. Mutations in the TGF signaling pathway can result in abnormal development of these tissues, impaired wound healing, and various types of cancers. However, holoprosencephaly and midfacial malformations would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Homeobox (HOX) proteins play an essential role in the organization of the embryo in a craniocaudal direction. Mutations in HOX genes typically cause malformations and malpositioning of the developing limbs. However, holoprosencephaly and midfacial malformations would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

The fibroblast growth factor (FGF) protein family is responsible for the lengthening of the developing limbs of the embryo via stimulating mitosis in the mesoderm. FGF gene mutations, therefore, result in hypoplasia/aplasia of the limbs. However, holoprosencephaly and midfacial malformations would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

The Wnt-7 protein of the Wnt protein family plays a role in cellular growth and proliferation at the distal end of the developing limbs as well as in dorsal-ventral patterning during the embryonic development of various structures (e.g., urogenital tract). Mutations in the Wnt signaling pathway may result in limb malformations. However, holoprosencephaly and midfacial malformations would not be expected.
questions.hint: This newborn has alobar holoprosencephaly, which is characterized by a monoventricle and fused basal ganglia. This condition is commonly associated with facial malformations such as a single nostril, cleft lip, or a single incisor, all of which can be caused by a mutation in a gene that is involved in the formation of a midline in the ventral forebrain and maintaining anteroposterior limb polarity.

questions.text: A  29-year-old primigravid woman at 18 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. She works as a paralegal and lives with her husband. Her current pregnancy was unexpected, and she did not take any prenatal medications or supplements. Physical examination shows a uterus 2 inches above the umbilicus. The concentration of α-fetoprotein in the maternal serum and concentrations of both α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase in the amniotic fluid are elevated. Ultrasonography of the uterus shows an increased amniotic fluid volume. The fetus most likely has which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Holoprosencephaly results from failure of the embryonic prosencephalon to separate into two cerebral hemispheres, leading to brain malformation of varying severity as well as midline craniofacial defects. The etiology is thought to be multifactorial, including both genetic (e.g., trisomy 13, mutations in sonic hedgehog signaling pathway) and environmental (e.g., alcohol and retinoic acid exposure in utero) components. Holoprosencephaly can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography and fetal MRI; however, polyhydramnios is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, this defect is not associated with increased α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid.

B) INCORRECT:

Lissencephaly results from failure of neuronal cell migration, thereby inhibiting development of the gyri and sulci. This malformation is typically genetic but may also be caused by viral infections or insufficient intrauterine perfusion in early pregnancy. Lissencephaly is often diagnosed at birth or soon after via imaging; however, polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasonography is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, lissencephaly is not associated with increased α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid.

C) INCORRECT:

Spina bifida occulta is a neural tube defect (NTD) that results from failure of the caudal neuropore to close. Folate deficiency, which this patient likely has (lack of prenatal supplements), is associated with an increased risk of NTDs. However, spina bifida occulta is a closed NTD and would, therefore, not show increased α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid. Moreover, this defect is not associated with polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasonography. Spina bifida occulta is most commonly diagnosed postnatally based on typical cutaneous findings (i.e., small dimple or tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region).

D) INCORRECT:

Myelomeningocele is a neural tube defect (NTD) that results from failure of the caudal neuropore to close. Folate deficiency, which this patient likely has (lack of prenatal supplements), is associated with an increased risk of NTDs. Myelomeningocele is an open NTD that would show increased α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid, as seen here. However, this defect is not associated with polyhydramnios but is rather diagnosed based on vertebral irregularities (e.g., U-shaped vertebral body, bulging of the fetal back) on prenatal ultrasonography.
Image Description:

Ultrasound of 21-week fetus (sagittal plane)

A myelomeningocele sac (green overlay) is identified at the lumbar region. The sac contains anechoic fluid and some solid neural elements.

T: thorax

E) CORRECT:

Anencephaly is a lethal neural tube defect (NTD) characterized by an open cranial vault and absence of the forebrain. The most important risk factor associated with NTDs is folate deficiency, either due to dietary shortage or the consumption of folic acid antagonists (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Because anencephaly is an open NTD that leaves the neural tube exposed, α-fetoprotein (AFP) and acetylcholinesterase (AChE) can diffuse freely into the amniotic fluid and maternal serum. If both AFP and AChE are elevated in the amniotic fluid, fetal NTDs can be diagnosed with high accuracy, even if ultrasonography is inconclusive.
questions.hint: This fetus's condition results from failure of closure of the rostral neuropore during embryogenesis. The increased amniotic fluid volume (i.e., polyhydramnios) seen here is due to impaired fetal swallowing.

questions.text: A 2710-g (6-lb) female newborn is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old primigravid woman following a spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother received routine prenatal care, which was unremarkable. Apgar scores are 7 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination shows skin dimpling and a tuft of hair over the gluteal cleft. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Failure of which of the following embryological processes is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Failed closure of the rostral neuropore during neurulation causes anencephaly, which is characterized by an open cranial vault and absence or underdevelopment of the forebrain and large portions of the skull. Anencephaly is usually detected on routine prenatal ultrasound and laboratory studies (i.e., increased maternal serum α-fetoprotein) and is incompatible with life.

B) INCORRECT:

Failure of neuronal cell migration from the ventricular zone to the cortical zone during weeks 12–24 of gestation leads to lissencephaly, which is characterized by underdevelopment of cortical sulci and gyri of the brain. Lissencephaly typically manifests with microcephaly, craniofacial abnormalities, seizures, and hypotonia.

C) CORRECT:

Spina bifida is the incomplete fusion of vertebral arches (typically affecting the lower lumbar or sacral spine) that results from incomplete closure of the caudal neuropore during neurulation. Although spina bifida occulta is considered to be a neural tube defect, the spinal cord, meninges, and overlying skin remain intact. The skin overlying the defect may be dysplastic, manifesting as skin dimpling, a hair tuft, and/or lipoma. Spina bifida occulta is not usually detected on routine prenatal ultrasound, and maternal serum α-fetoprotein is normal because the lesion is covered by skin. The condition does not manifest with neurological symptoms and may be an incidental finding on imaging later in life.

Meningocele, myelocele, and myelomeningocele are open neural tube defects that are characterized by the herniation of meningeal and/or neural tissue through the vertebral defect. Due to the exposure of the tissue to the surrounding environment (e.g., amniotic fluid), these conditions are usually associated with severe neurological deficits (e.g., lower limb paralysis, bowel and bladder incontinence) and can be detected on routine prenatal ultrasound and laboratory studies (i.e., increased maternal serum α-fetoprotein).

D) INCORRECT:

Failed fusion of the neural folds during neurulation leads to myeloschisis, which is the most severe subtype of neural tube defects. Myeloschisis manifests with bare, exposed neural tissue that is not covered by meninges, bones, or skin. Additionally, features such as club foot, joint contractures, and flaccid paralysis are typical. Myeloschisis is usually detected on routine prenatal ultrasound or laboratory studies (i.e., increased maternal serum α-fetoprotein).
questions.hint: Skin dimpling and hair tuft over the gluteal cleft suggest spina bifida occulta.

questions.text: A 2550-g (5 lb 10 oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. Labor and delivery were uncomplicated but the mother did not receive prenatal care. Examination of the newborn shows hypotonia in the lower extremities and a red, fleshy swelling without overlying skin in the lumbosacral region. Clear yellow fluid leaks from the superior margin of the swelling. Ultrasonography of the swelling shows a fluid-filled sac containing herniated neural tissue. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Nondisjunction of the neural tube and surface ectoderm
Cystic dilation in the central canal

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Myelomeningocele is a disorder of primary neurulation that results from the failure of the posterior (caudal) neuropore to close at 3–4 weeks' gestation. While myelomeningoceles can usually be detected on routine prenatal ultrasound or laboratory studies (i.e., serum α-fetoprotein), this patient's mother did not receive any prenatal care. Moreover, a folate deficiency due to a lack of prenatal vitamins is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects. Symptoms including lower extremity paralysis and sensory deficits, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and cognitive impairment are often present from birth, as seen here. Additional evaluation, including a head MRI, should be performed because approximately 95% of patients with myelomeningocele have an associated Chiari II malformation.

Anencephaly is also a disorder of primary neurulation, and results from the failure of the anterior (rostral) neuropore closure.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in cerebrospinal fluid pressure can cause hydrocephalus, which can occur concomitantly with myelomeningocele with a Chiari II malformation. However, hydrocephalus alone would not explain the swelling containing neural tissue on this patient's lumbosacrum. Additionally, because the fontanelles in infants are open, neurological symptoms associated with hydrocephalus may not manifest at birth. Moreover, once symptoms do present, spasticity and hyperreflexia would be expected, not hypotonia.

C) INCORRECT:

Nondisjunction of the neural tube and surface ectoderm would result in spina bifida occulta, a disorder of secondary neurulation. This nondisjunction results in failure to form the posterior vertebral arch and may result in lumbosacral swelling, as seen here. However, the cerebrospinal fluid and neural tissue are contained underneath a skin barrier in spinal bifida occulta and may only be noticeable by a dimple or tuft of hair. Moreover, most patients with spina bifida occulta are asymptomatic, and hypotonia would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Defective neuronal migration at 3–5 months gestation can cause lissencephaly, which results in the underdevelopment of gyri and sulci in the brain. While lissencephaly can result in hypotonia, a lumbosacral swelling containing neural tissue would not be expected. Moreover, additional signs and symptoms, including microcephaly, ventriculomegaly, and craniofacial abnormalities, would be expected in a patient with lissencephaly.

E) INCORRECT:

The proliferation of totipotent germ cells can result in the formation of germ cell tumors, which can also manifest with a protrusion. However, the most common germ cell tumors in newborns are sacrococcygeal teratomas, which manifest in the sacrococcygeal region, not the lumbosacral region. Moreover, no neural tissue would be expected to be present in the protrusion.

F) INCORRECT:

A cystic dilation in the central canal suggests syringomyelia, which also causes hypotonia in the lower extremities. However, syringomyelia is most common in the cervical region, where symptoms often present in a cape-like distribution prior to manifesting in the lower extremities. Additionally, syringomyelia is not associated with a lumbosacral swelling containing neural tissue because the syrinx is most often located within the spinal cord and therefore not visible on the skin. Moreover, this condition usually manifests at 30–40 years of age, rather than immediately postnatal.
questions.hint: A lumbosacral swelling that is not covered by skin, leaks CSF, and contains neural tissue is suggestive of myelomeningocele.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of a painful rash in the genital area. She also developed mild nausea and decreased appetite during the last 4 weeks. She has not seen a physician in several years; her immunization records are unavailable. Her menstrual cycle is irregular, and she does not recall when her last menstrual period was. She drinks two to three beers daily and occasionally smokes cigarettes. She has several male sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows a group of small vesicles on an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora with tender, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Ultrasonography discloses an intrauterine pregnancy consistent with 14 weeks' gestation with no detectable heartbeat. The fetal cranial vault is absent, there is no visible brain tissue, and there is mild polyhydramnios. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented the defect in this fetus?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy can lead to teratogenic damage in the fetus and cause fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). FAS is associated with certain central nervous system abnormalities, such as microcephaly and holoprosencephaly, but it does not cause NTDs.

B) INCORRECT:

Maternal smoking during pregnancy is associated with intrauterine growth restriction, stillbirth, and congenital malformations (e.g., cleft lip, gastroschisis, anal atresia, cardiac defects, renal hypoplasia). Although smoking is associated with a slight increase in the risk of NTDs, another cause is more likely responsible for the anencephaly seen in this fetus.

C) CORRECT:

Folate is an essential coenzyme required for DNA synthesis and cell division. In the setting of increased metabolic demand from pregnancy, folate supplementation is often necessary to prevent deficiency, which can result in NTDs (e.g., spina bifida, meningomyelocele, encephalocele, anencephaly). This patient's lack of prenatal care resulted in folate deficiency and subsequent fetal anencephaly. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends daily supplementation of 0.4–0.8 mg oral folic acid for all individuals capable of pregnancy for at least ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive, and supplementation should be continued until 12 weeks' gestation.

D) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir therapy is used to treat genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which typically manifests with painful genital vesicles and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, both of which are seen in this patient. Acyclovir therapy also prevents vertical transmission of HSV. Though congenital HSV infection can manifest with central nervous system defects, such as microcephaly and hydrocephalus, it does not cause NTDs, including anencephaly.

E) INCORRECT:

Penicillin therapy is used to treat syphilis, which typically manifests with genital lesions, lymphadenopathy, and mild fever. This patient's history of multiple sexual partners with inconsistent condom use increases her risk of syphilis. However, the genital lesions and lymphadenopathy associated with syphilis are painless. In addition, congenital syphilis typically manifests with hepatomegaly, placentomegaly, and polyhydramnios on fetal ultrasonography; it is not associated with NTDs.
questions.hint: An absent cranial vault and no visible brain tissue on fetal ultrasonography indicate anencephaly, a neural tube defect (NTD).

questions.text:
A 42-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 18 weeks and 2 days’ gestation by unsure last menstrual period undergoes the quadruple marker test. Her alpha-fetoprotein level is found to be 4.0 multiples of the median.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's care?

choices.text: Refer for ultrasonography to determine gestational age
Refer the patient to a genetic counselor and offer a diagnostic test
Reassure the patient that her alpha-fetoprotein level is normal for her age
Repeat the quadruple marker test in 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis may be offered as part of diagnostic testing to women with elevated AFP levels who have accurate gestational dating. However, many centers now use specialized sonography as the primary method of evaluating an elevated serum AFP. Most women no longer opt for amniocentesis because of the small risk of miscarriage associated with it and because of the accuracy of ultrasound. Should women elect to have amniocentesis, the sensitivity of this test is about 98% for open neural-tube defects, with a false-positive rate of 0.4%.

B) CORRECT:

Maternal alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) evaluation is an effective screening test for neural-tube defects. However, it has a high false-positive rate. Only 2% of women with an AFP level above the cutoff (usually defined as ≥2.0 multiples of the median) are carrying a fetus with a neural-tube defect.

In general, women with an AFP level above the cutoff should be referred for genetic counseling and diagnostic testing. However, if there is uncertainty about gestational age (as in this case), an ultrasound should be performed first. Once the true gestational age is determined, the AFP result can be interpreted more readily.

Ideally, women and their partners should be counseled about the implications of a positive quadruple marker test before the test is performed.

Key learning point: The appropriate follow-up for an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level in a woman with uncertainty about gestational age is ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

In general, women with an AFP level above the cutoff should be referred for genetic counseling and diagnostic testing. However, if there is uncertainty about gestational age (as in this case), an ultrasound should be performed first. Once the true gestational age is determined, the AFP result can be interpreted more readily.

D) INCORRECT:

Maternal alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) evaluation is an effective screening test for neural-tube defects. However, it has a high false-positive rate. Only 2% of women with an AFP level above the cutoff (usually defined as ≥2.0 multiples of the median) are carrying a fetus with a neural-tube defect.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeating the quadruple marker test again in 2 weeks would not yield results that are any more interpretable than the current set of results.

questions.text:
A 10-month-old boy who has been circumcised is hospitalized for a urinary tract infection (UTI), his third since birth. He had a normal voiding cystourethrogram after the second UTI and is being treated empirically with ceftriaxone.
On examination, his vital signs are within normal limits. He moves his arms spontaneously and without difficulty, but his legs have few spontaneous movements, and he refuses to bear weight on them. He has normal upper-extremity deep-tendon reflexes and 5 beats of clonus at the ankles bilaterally. His electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within normal limits for his age.
Which one of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ear pits and tags can be associated with genitourinary anomalies, but the constellation of findings and normal renal imaging in this case are more suggestive of a neural tube defect.

B) INCORRECT:

Leg hemihypertrophy is a clinical feature of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome but is not associated with OSD. A spinal dysraphism would affect both legs, and the patient would develop atrophy rather than hypertrophy.

C) CORRECT:

The combination of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), delayed gross-motor milestones, and lower-extremity weakness and spasticity in this infant is concerning for an occult spinal dysraphism (OSD).

OSD encompass a wide variety of skin-covered neural-tube defects. Unlike open neural-tube defects, which are often detected prenatally during fetal anatomic surveys and are apparent at birth, OSD may remain undiagnosed until later in life, when complications have already arisen. Such complications include chronic UTIs, lower-limb deformity and weakness, bowel or bladder dysfunction, pain, and lower-extremity paralysis or spasticity.

More than 50% of children with OSD are found to have sacrococcygeal cutaneous lesions, such as:
• duplicated gluteal cleft or asymmetric gluteal creases
• hypertrichosis, hemangioma, or lipoma in the midline over the spine
• caudal appendage
• dimples located >2.5 cm above the anal verge or measuring >5 mm in diameter
• multiple dimples or dimples that are not midline
The presence of any of these lesions should prompt radiographic evaluation for OSD. Ultrasound is typically used in infants younger than 3 months, and MRI is used in older infants. Surgery is the mainstay of treatment for OSD. Solitary sacral dimples with skin visible covering the base are common and benign.

Key learning point: The most common presentation of occult spinal dysraphism is a sacrococcygeal cutaneous lesion, such as a duplicated gluteal cleft.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermal melanocytosis, which typically appears as a flat bluish-gray lesion with irregular borders overlying the sacrum, is not associated with OSD. It is a benign finding and will fade over time, usually in the first year or two of life.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemangiomas are associated with occult spinal dysraphism only if they are in the midline over the spine.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office for preconceptional advice. She has been married for 2 years and would like to conceive within the next year. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and follows a balanced diet. She takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. She has adequate knowledge of the fertile days of her menstrual cycle. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supplementation of folic acid (0.4–0.8 mg/day) is recommended in all patients trying to conceive. Ideally, women should begin taking a supplement ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continue with this dose until 12 weeks of gestational age to meet the increased demand of folate due to fetal neural tube development and maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. If there is a folate deficiency, neural tube defects (e.g., anencephaly, meningomyelocele) and megaloblastic anemia may occur.

B) INCORRECT:

In the absence of severe deficiency, excessive intake of vitamin A is contraindicated in pregnant women and women who may become pregnant within the next 60 days. Vitamin A doses greater than the recommended dietary allowance in pregnancy (> 770 mcg/day or > 2560 units/day) may cause craniofacial malformations or central nervous system, heart, or thymus abnormalities in the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 supplementation is recommended for pregnant women who adhere to a vegan diet since vitamin B12 is mainly found in red meat, fish, and dairy products. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to maternal and fetal megaloblastic anemia. This patient does not follow a vegan diet and is not yet pregnant, making vitamin B12 supplementation unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation of 30–60 mg/d is recommended during pregnancy to meet the increased iron demand due to maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. Iron deficiency in pregnancy may cause maternal and fetal anemia and increases the risk of placental insufficiency. Since this patient shows no symptoms of iron deficiency anemia, such as fatigue or pallor, iron supplementation is not necessary prior to conception.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who are underweight can experience difficulty conceiving. If the patient were underweight and having problems becoming pregnant, gaining weight might be advised. Gaining extra weight prior to conception is not necessary in this case, as the woman has a normal BMI. Over the course of pregnancy, she should gain 25–35 lbs (about 11–16 kg).
questions.hint: Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of neural tube defects such as spina bifida and anencephaly in the fetus?

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman preparing for pregnancy asks how to reduce fetal neural defects. What is the best recommendation?

choices.text: High-folate diet without supplements until early pregnancy
Second trimester initiation of prenatal vitamins
Vitamin B₁₂ supplementation after a positive pregnancy test
0.4 mg folate daily at least one month before conception

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a high-folate diet includes foods like leafy greens and legumes, dietary folate alone may not provide consistent or sufficient levels to prevent neural tube defects. The neural tube closes early in development, often before pregnancy is recognized, making preconception folic acid supplementation essential.

B) INCORRECT:

The neural tube closes around 28 days post-conception, well before the second trimester. Starting prenatal vitamins in the second trimester does not provide folate during the critical period for neural tube closure, which is essential for preventing neural tube defects.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B₁₂ is important for cellular division and neurological function, but it does not prevent neural tube defects. The critical period for neural tube closure is within the first 28 days of gestation, often before pregnancy is confirmed. Preconception folic acid supplementation is the established preventive strategy for NTDs.

D) CORRECT:

Folic acid supplementation is crucial for preventing neural tube defects (NTDs) such as spina bifida and anencephaly. Neural tube formation completes by 28 days post-conception, often before pregnancy recognition. Taking 0.4 mg of folate daily at least one month before conception ensures adequate folate levels for early embryologic development. Major health organizations recommend this preconception approach to reduce NTD risk.

Key learning point: Folic acid supplementation is recommended for women planning to become pregnant to reduce the risk of neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman planning pregnancy asks how to reduce neural tube defect risk. What is the most appropriate advice?

choices.text: No supplementation needed without a family history of neural tube defects
Folic acid only after confirming pregnancy
4 mg of folic acid daily from the second trimester onward
0.4 mg of folic acid daily starting at least one month before conception

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Most neural tube defects occur sporadically, not just in those with a family history. Folate deficiency is a key factor in their development. Guidelines recommend folic acid supplementation for all women planning pregnancy, as neural tube closure occurs early, often before pregnancy is confirmed.

B) INCORRECT:

Neural tube closure is completed by the fourth week of gestation, often before pregnancy confirmation. Starting folic acid only after confirming pregnancy may miss this critical period, failing to provide protective benefits. Guidelines recommend starting folic acid at least one month before conception to ensure optimal levels during neural tube formation.

C) INCORRECT:

Neural tube closure occurs by 28 days post-conception, requiring adequate folate levels early in pregnancy. The 4 mg dose is for high-risk women, such as those with a previous affected pregnancy. Starting in the second trimester is too late to prevent neural tube defects.

D) CORRECT:

Folic acid is essential for neural tube formation and closure, which occurs by the fourth week of gestation. Adequate folate levels before conception ensure sufficient resources for cell division and DNA synthesis, reducing neural tube defect risk. Guidelines recommend 0.4 mg of folic acid daily for women planning pregnancy, starting at least one month before conception, to optimize maternal folate stores before neural tube closure.

Key learning point: Folic acid supplementation is recommended during the preconception period to reduce the risk of neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

questions.text: You are seeing a 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 18 weeks’ gestation, who presents for her first prenatal visit. She works as a paralegal and lives with her husband. The pregnancy was unplanned, and she has not taken any prenatal medications or supplements. On examination, the uterus is palpated 2 inches above the umbilicus. Maternal serum α-fetoprotein and both α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase in the amniotic fluid are elevated. Ultrasonography shows increased amniotic fluid volume. Which one of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis in the fetus?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anencephaly is a lethal neural tube defect (NTD) characterized by an open cranial vault and absence of the forebrain. The most important risk factor associated with NTDs is folate deficiency, either due to dietary shortage or the consumption of folic acid antagonists (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine). Because anencephaly is an open NTD that leaves the neural tube exposed, α-fetoprotein (AFP) and acetylcholinesterase (AChE) can diffuse freely into the amniotic fluid and maternal serum. If both AFP and AChE are elevated in the amniotic fluid, fetal NTDs can be diagnosed with high accuracy, even if ultrasonography is inconclusive.

Key learning point: Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by elevated maternal serum and amniotic fluid α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase due to exposure of neural tissue.

B) INCORRECT:

Lissencephaly results from failure of neuronal cell migration, thereby inhibiting development of the gyri and sulci. This malformation is typically genetic but may also be caused by viral infections or insufficient intrauterine perfusion in early pregnancy. Lissencephaly is often diagnosed at birth or soon after via imaging; however, polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasonography is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, lissencephaly is not associated with increased α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid.

C) INCORRECT:

Myelomeningocele is a neural tube defect (NTD) that results from failure of the caudal neuropore to close. Folate deficiency, which this patient likely has (lack of prenatal supplements), is associated with an increased risk of NTDs. Myelomeningocele is an open NTD that would show increased α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid, as seen here. However, this defect is not associated with polyhydramnios but is rather diagnosed based on vertebral irregularities (e.g., U-shaped vertebral body, bulging of the fetal back) on prenatal ultrasonography.

D) INCORRECT:

Spina bifida occulta is a neural tube defect (NTD) that results from failure of the caudal neuropore to close. Folate deficiency, which this patient likely has (lack of prenatal supplements), is associated with an increased risk of NTDs. However, spina bifida occulta is a closed NTD and would, therefore, not show increased α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid. Moreover, this defect is not associated with polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasonography. Spina bifida occulta is most commonly diagnosed postnatally based on typical cutaneous findings (i.e., small dimple or tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region).

E) INCORRECT:

Holoprosencephaly results from failure of the embryonic prosencephalon to separate into two cerebral hemispheres, leading to brain malformation of varying severity as well as midline craniofacial defects. The etiology is thought to be multifactorial, including both genetic (e.g., trisomy 13, mutations in sonic hedgehog signaling pathway) and environmental (e.g., alcohol and retinoic acid exposure in utero) components. Holoprosencephaly can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography and fetal MRI; however, polyhydramnios is not a characteristic finding. Moreover, this defect is not associated with increased α-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase levels in the maternal serum or amniotic fluid.
questions.hint: This fetus's condition results from failure of closure of the rostral neuropore during embryogenesis. The increased amniotic fluid volume (i.e., polyhydramnios) seen here is due to impaired fetal swallowing.
